translation.en: [RED SNAPPER'S "QUICK TEMPER" PLAYING]
[PANTING]
[GRUNTS]
[TIRES SCREECHING] [HORN HONKING]
No. No, no, no. I know. Shh.
Hello, Mr. Davis.
My name is Jack Carter, and you don't wanna know me.
I know it's just one guy talking, but I'll be honest.
I don't understand what the big fricking deal is. I don't.
Listen, I told Fletcher I was gonna get him the money.
You shut up.
Give me a break, will you, Jack?
In all honestly, you haven't seen the guy
in, what, four, five years? He kicks,
and all of a sudden you give a shit?
Who are you, Father Mulcahy? I'm so not buying this,
it's not even funny, kemo sabe.
He was my little brother and he's dead.
He left a wife and kid. So I'm going. I owe him that.
Let me get this straight. Now you owe him?
Here's the bad news, sports fans: It's a little late.
Well, listen, the therapy session is good,
you know, because you need it. But why don't I
just go somewhere else? I'm gonna talk to--
You sit here and you shut your mouth
or this is going to the next level, you got that?
"Next level"? What is that, a catch phrase or something?
What the--? I mean...
Catch phrase?
Jack, Jack, Jack. Come on. Take it easy. Take it easy.
You're gonna give yourself a fucking heart attack.
Fletcher wants your ass here.
He's made that very clear. He wants you here.
I'm like a broken record.
If you don't take care of business,
the business will take care of you.
The business will take care of you.
I'm taking care of business. Whatever.
What time's your flight? I'm not flying.
Beg your pardon? Not flying, Connie.
Uh-huh. So would you say
you got something special working there?
What are you carrying? Knives, guns, flamethrowers?
Got something you're not telling Con-a-won-a-doo-da-day about?
I'm back in a couple of days.
Right, but... Jack?
[TRAIN HORN BLOWING]
[BRAKES SQUEALING] [TRAIN CROSSING ALERT RINGING]
[RAINDROPS PATTERING]
[MOBY'S "MEMORY GOSPEL" PLAYING]
What are you doing here?
I came to pay my respects.
He could've used your respect while he was still alive.
[SIGHS]
Is Doreen around?
Yeah, she's around.
PRIEST: "I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills,
from whence cometh my help.
My help cometh from the Lord, which made Heaven and Earth.
He will not suffer thy foot to be moved:
He that keepeth thee will not slumber.
Behold, He that keepeth Israel shall neither slumber nor sleep.
The Lord is thy keeper.
The Lord is thy shade upon thy right hand.
The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night.
The Lord shall preserve thee from all evil.
He shall preserve thy soul.
The Lord shall preserve thy going out
and thy coming in from this day forth
and even for evermore. Amen."
How you doing? I'm Jack, Richie's brother.
Oh, shit, man. Hi, I'm Eddie.
I worked with him over at the George.
Eddie, let me ask you a question.
Was my brother into something?
Richie? No, man.
He wasn't that type of guy.
I'm very sorry about your father.
Don't feel sorry for me.
You don't know me.
You're a picture on a piano.
Hey.
Hold up a second, would you?
I couldn't help noticing you.
You stand out in a crowd.
I'm Jack, Richie's brother.
Oh.
I'm real sorry. He was a great guy.
Yeah.
So, uh, where'd you know Richard from?
Around the bar.
You know how it goes.
No.
Why don't you tell me, how's it go?
Look, I really don't know you well enough to get personal.
JACK: Let me ask you. You think something could've happened
between the last time you saw him
and when the accident did happen?
EDDIE: I don't know. Maybe, I guess.
JACK: But you would know if something was off, right?
Shit, man, I don't know. I guess. Yeah, maybe.
Jack, that is enough.
It's enough.
[GUESTS MURMURING]
What are you gonna do, rough me up?
[SIGHS]
I'd kind of like to be alone.
Sure.
I'm fine, all right? I just came out for a smoke.
You know, Doreen, you don't know me very well,
and what you do know, you don't seem to like very much.
I'm gonna be here over the weekend,
so if you need anything, anything at all,
I'll be staying at the Mercer Hotel, okay?
He didn't drink, you know. What?
My dad.
He wouldn't drink and drive.
So, what do you think happened?
I don't know.
Maybe...
I don't know. Forget it.
He's dead, all right. What's it matter?
Tell my mom I'll be home later.
LES [OVER PHONE]: What'd I tell you? What'd I say?
Which part of "I can't let you go"
did you not under-fucking-stand?
This is your job.
This is not a fricking charity case.
You do your job.
Now, I want your butt down here tomorrow.
I am the boss, Jack. Okay?
Got me?
JACK: I can't believe you guys kept this cat.
Richie and I, we used to hide stuff from our mom
underneath all the cookies.
I'm pretty sure she knew, but I don't think she really cared.
[CHUCKLES]
So were you two guys okay?
What? I mean, you and Richie...
I mean, before the accident, were you two getting along okay?
What kind of question is that? Well, it's just a question.
Was he drinking a lot more? More than normal?
Wha--? Jack.
It's just Eddie said he didn't see him drink much.
And Doreen said he wouldn't drink and drive.
So I'm just wondering-- Oh, Jack. What are you doing?
What? Why do you care all of a sudden?
Because he's dead?
Where were you when he was alive?
He was your brother.
You disappeared on him, now he's gone.
So, what am I supposed to do?
Take a trip down memory lane with you?
Catch you up on how he was doing?
What do you think you're gonna do,
come in here and fix things?
You don't fix things, Jack.
You break things.
Remember?
[LINE RINGING]
Hello, it's Connie. Yeah, it's me.
Jack. What do you say, Jack?
Fucking white of you to call.
Fletcher just ripped me a new asshole.
You on your way back?
No, I wanna stay a little while.
Oh, come on. Who do you think's
taking the heat here? We're partners.
Look it up, it'll say, "If you're screwed, I'm screwed."
He wants you here. You need a written invitation?
I got some things to do.
Okay. Okay, Jack, here's the truth as I know it.
I don't know how much longer I can cover your ass.
Are we gonna see Fletcher, or what?
Absolutely. We are flying in. We are there.
You got something to say? What do you wanna say?
It's time for you to chop it up with the big dog.
Because I'm hearing talk, Jack. People are talking.
About you and Audrey.
I don't know how long I can keep that from him.
They must be hearing it from you.
Am I right? Oh, you simple bitch.
I'm covering your ass. Do you hear me?
I'm covering your ass! You better cover your own ass.
[CUSTOMERS CHATTERING]
Which way is Brumby's office?
No, you listen. I don't wanna hear you can't find it.
This was supposed to be done.
A guy died the other night.
Can you hold on a second?
Can I help you with something? I'm Jack Carter.
Richie's brother.
I'll call you right back.
Uh, Christ. I'm sorry I wasn't at the funeral,
but I never could take them.
Would you like some coffee or something?
No, I'm fine, thanks.
He was a good bloke, Richie was.
Saved my ass a lot of money just by doing a solid job.
So how long was he running this place for you?
Well, since we've been up. About five years.
Five years and no problems? None.
No enemies?
Well, not that I know of.
I mean, he was an easygoing sort of bloke.
Does he seem like a guy that would get dead drunk
and go out driving in a rainstorm?
Not to me. Me either.
Where is this going?
I think he was taken out.
Taken out?
Richie?
Why would you say that?
There's something you're not telling me, Cliff.
What the hell does that mean? Just relax.
Listen, I don't like hard cases coming in here
and talking to me like I know something.
If there's someone putting out something about me,
I wanna know who it is. When I know what is it
and who's saying it, I might take the matter up with you.
Mightn't I?
You're a big man, but you're out of shape.
With me, it's a full-time job. So please, sit down.
Thank you.
Now, I know you got security cameras around the bar.
Did the police ask to look at the tapes?
Why would they? It was drunk driving.
Mind if I do?
That's got the whole night on it.
Did you talk to Geraldine? Who's Geraldine?
Oh, Christ. How am I gonna put this?
She was his, uh, lady on the side.
His innamorata.
You know this for sure?
What can I tell you? It wasn't a big thing.
Not many people knew about it.
JACK: Cyrus.
How you doing?
Holy shit.
Well, if it ain't the Vegas man with the Vegas tan.
Geraldine, right?
Been a long time. Yeah, Jack.
It's been a very long time.
Listen, I heard about Richie, man.
That's pretty messed up. Yeah.
You got my deepest condolences and all that shit.
I appreciate that.
So you still running with Fletcher?
Why not? How are you making a living?
Well, I'm making. With who?
With somebody. What do you care? JACK: I don't care.
I just wanna know if you're still a bottom-feeder.
Oh, let me tell you something, Jack.
You see all this shit here? You see it?
This is the new world, brother. I'm online.
These are my girls, my business.
While you're running around chasing deadbeats
for some fucking asshole,
I'm swimming in the big pool, baby.
I got the juice around here now.
I hooked up with this freak and this foreign guy.
Created my own little empire.
Look at you.
The little man versus the start-up.
You got a problem with me?
Let me tell you something, Jack.
I think you should take a very big moment
and just think about where you are.
Because this ain't yesterday, slick.
Relax, I'm just playing with you a little bit.
Oh, yeah, I get that.
Don't put your hands on me.
Come on, let me see your eyes.
Come on.
Whatever turns you on, Jack.
Still pretty? Hm?
Yeah.
Like cat piss in the snow.
See you around.
[TECHNO MUSIC PLAYING OVER SPEAKERS]
Hey, you can't come-- Hey, you can't come in here.
Hey, mate, where you going?
Is this the part where I'm supposed to be scared?
You Carter?
That's right.
And you really don't wanna know me.
[BOTH GRUNTING]
Shit, it's good to be home.
Damn you, Cyrus, I never met the guy.
Get off. I don't know him. Shut up and get in the car.
[ENGINE STARTS, REVVING]
Good afternoon, sir. Are you a member?
I'm here with Mr. Franklin.
Go right ahead.
GOLFER: Hey, pal, you're walking on my line.
CYRUS: Just smile, sweetheart, and get rid of the guy, okay?
Nice stroke.
Who the fuck are you?
Tiger Woods.
I'm gonna go get security, all right?
Can I help you, sir? I don't know.
Ahem, are you from the club? Is there a problem?
My brother died the other night, and now I'm here.
Listen, uh, Mr-- Carter.
Carter. Mr. Carter. Um...
I'm real sorry about your brother, that sucks.
MAN: Jeremy, what's up? But I can't help you here.
So, what I suggest you do is contact my outreach program
over at the offices-- Mind if we talk a minute?
Uh, yes. Yes, I mind.
I was under the impression this was a private club. Heh.
I think we should go someplace and talk.
Okay, listen, scary man-- I scare you?
Okay, whatever this is, it isn't going over real well, so...
Why don't you drive me back to my car?
We can talk on the way. Is that a problem?
Yeah, it is a problem. No, no.
It's a problem if you don't.
Come on. It's okay. Come on.
MAN: Jeremy?
So, what's your name? Jeremy Kinnear.
Maybe you've read about me in Forbes.
No, I don't do that, Jeremy.
So, what are you telling me, you're bucks-up?
Well, without blowing the proverbial horn
my computer company is worth about a gazillion dollars.
Give or take. Your folks must be very proud.
I paid off my student loans, bought them a house in France.
They leave me alone.
I think we've got a mutual acquaintance, Jeremy.
JEREMY: Oh, really? Yeah. Cyrus Paice.
Yeah, I know him.
I try not to spend too much time around him though.
What's the connection? I don't see it.
[CHUCKLES SOFTLY]
You know, Mr. Carter, I really don't have
to answer your questions.
[TIRES SCREECHING]
Sure you do, Jeremy.
What's the connection?
Okay, Mr. Carter, fine.
You know, um...
when you spend most of your life stuck behind a computer
things like golf and girls
become pretty important, you know?
But they don't go real well with the glasses
and pocket-protector image my stockholders prefer.
So-- So he pulls for you.
You know why I like golf, Mr. Carter?
Because the ball just keeps going away.
[CHUCKLES]
The only sport where you hit that little sucker
and it doesn't come back at you.
I've gotta want to go after it and get it.
And when I get to it...
Pfft!
I just knock it away again.
[LAUGHS]
You see what I'm saying, Mr. Carter?
Once I get rid of it...
I never wanna see it again.
He said his brother died the other night and now he's here.
He's here. You get me? We are fucked.
STAFFER: Excuse me, Mr. Kinnear.
Can you get your feet off the table?
Yes, sorry. Sure.
No. No, no. You listen. Listen to me. Listen to me.
You asked me to get you online. I did that for you. Fair trade.
Then you start this porn thing. I say, "keep me clean,"
but you can't do that. I don't wanna think what happens
if he's already taken that to the police.
How'd he get it, anyway? They're supposed to go
straight to the hard drive. You--
Goddamn right I'm freaking out.
I'm a fucking Harvard grad. I do not do porn.
No, no, no. Shh, shh, shh, shh!
I don't want to know what happened the other night.
I don't care.
It's none of my business.
I just want the big brother gone.
I don't mean "gone" like you goned the other guy.
I mean, away. I want him away. I want you away.
I want the whole thing done.
[SOMA SONIC'S "FALLING" PLAYING]
[SIGHS]
[PHONE RINGING]
Hello?
Where's the big bad wolf?
Out with the pigs, I guess.
He wants you to come back-- Look, Audrey. Listen.
I was thinking that, uh, when I get back, you and me
we gotta get out of Vegas for good, you know.
Jack, I can't do this.
Do what? You and me.
Les Fletcher is my job. It's what I do.
You...
You're...
You're something different.
All right, fine.
You ought to get out of there, with or without me
but you ought to get out there. LES: Hey, Audrey.
Audrey! I'm up here.
Get your ass down here. I gotta go.
[CHUCKLES]
Yeah, that's good.
Another time, another place, huh?
Yeah.
Bye.
[DIAL TONE OVER PHONE]
GLORIA: You know, I sometimes feel
I'm gonna be alone for the rest of my life.
I wake up in the morning and look at my little girl
and I wonder when it was we became strangers.
She's all I have now, Jack, and I--
You know, I want her back so bad
and I don't even know where she went.
She won't talk to me. She won't even yell at me.
Oh, my God.
Who are you? What?
I mean, I'm just trying to make sense of this... of you.
You disappear off the face of the earth
for like five years and then come back and you...
[CHUCKLES]
You come back and--
I don't know, you look like Frank Sinatra or something.
And I just can't figure you out.
You know, it's not that big a deal, Gloria.
You know... everything changes, they say.
Why not me?
I just wanna try to do something right. Once.
Yeah, well, what is that, though?
What's right, Jack, you know?
You're too late to be Richie's brother.
You can't be Doreen's father.
And you can't be my man.
So I just don't know where you fit.
Maybe I don't.
Maybe I don't.
[SIGHS]
I'm sorry.
[THUNDER RUMBLING]
[BRUSH SCRAPING]
[SIGHS]
[ELECTRONIC DANCE MUSIC PLAYING OVER SPEAKERS]
JACK: Eddie.
You know Geraldine. What?
Geraldine. Do you know where she lives?
I don't know, man. The girl that hung around--
The girl that hung around with Richie,
do you know where she lives?
A girl? What? Come on.
[SNIFFS]
So you know Doreen much?
Uh, yeah, a little.
Hey, it's right up here on the left.
So, uh, you done with me, man?
No. Sit tight, I'll be right back.
WOMAN [ON TV]: Wouldn't be this great to give to your mother this year?
Oh, yes, of course. Thanks for coming.
Relax, everything is okay. How you doing?
I'm looking for Geraldine. You know where she is?
[HAIR DRYER BLOWING]
What was Richard to you?
[HAIR DRYER SHUTS OFF]
You can't just break into my house.
What was he to you?
I told you.
I met him at the bar.
He was just a guy I met.
That's all.
That's all?
He was nicer than most. Did you know he was married?
Look-- Did you know that?
What do you want?
I talked to him, okay? It's not a crime.
I gotta be somewhere.
I wanna know what happened.
You don't wanna know.
Geraldine.
Look at me.
Look at me.
I didn't come up here to hurt you.
I just wanna know what happened.
Richie wanted me to leave with him.
He and his wife weren't getting along so well.
Hardly spoke, you know?
They were gonna get divorced.
He wanted me to run away,
someplace like New York or something.
I said I couldn't do that, you know?
I got my own life here.
Yeah.
So I went to the bar to say goodbye,
and he followed me out.
And he makes this big scene outside the bar.
I hear he got pretty drunk.
Look, I don't wanna talk about this anymore.
[GRUNTS SOFTLY]
The keys are in it.
THORPEY: Carter.
Looks like the rain must have backed up the sewer.
How you been, man?
Still hanging around here, Thorpey?
I like it here.
I gotta have a word with you, all right?
And, uh, confidential.
You just stay in the car. I'll listen.
So, what do you wanna tell me?
How you been, man? I mean, you look good.
Thank you. I'm losing sleep here. So, what do you want?
Here, take this. It's free.
Alaska Airlines, first class. That's nice.
And who do I have to thank?
I've been asked to make sure you get on that plane. Tonight.
[CHUCKLES]
Whatever they're paying you, it ain't gonna be enough.
Hey!
[GROANS]
Come on. What you wanna do, boy? Come on, cowboy.
You wanna get rough? Come on. Take your best shot. Come on.
Come on, shoot him.
You got the stuff?
Put the gun down. JACK: Got the balls?
Let's see you do it. Go on.
Put it down. Put it down.
Big man. Big man.
♪ When dealing With an armed man ♪
♪ The best course of action Is to run ♪
[TIRES SCREECHING]
[GRUNTS]
[HORNS HONKING] [TIRES SCREECHING]
Whoa!
[MUMBLES]
Come on. Come on.
Come on. Come on.
Hey, hey, hey. Come on.
[WOMAN SCREAMING] [MAN GROANS]
WOMAN: Get back!
MAN: Get down! THORPEY: Out of the way.
[YELLING]
Watch out!
[TIRES SCREECHING]
[TRUCK HORN BLARING]
Oh, shit.
[GROANS]
Shit!
[PANTING]
[BOAT HORN BLARING IN DISTANCE]
THORPEY: Okay. Okay.
[SIGHS]
[YELLS]
Fuck.
Come on, the ride's over. Asked me to deliver the ticket
because you used to hang around my brother.
I knew you wouldn't go for it. Who sent you?
I can't tell you. You can't?
Did you have something to do with my brother?
I had nothing to do with your brother.
Then give me a name, or you're history.
[TECHNO MUSIC PLAYING]
Brumby's in the back.
[PANTING]
Carter? So now you're a travel agent.
What? That was a real nice touch,
sending Thorpey, very nostalgic.
What the hell are you talking about?
What'd Richie have on you?
Bloody hell, Jack. Richie was my friend.
What does it take, a fucking miracle for you to believe that?
You're not giving me anything here.
Oh, Jack, Jack, Jack.
Jack, stop that. Stop it, for fuck's sake.
Look, okay. I owed this bloke some money.
He fronted a truckload last year to extend the club.
He calls me this afternoon, says he'll wipe the slate clean
if I'll do this thing for him.
He said he wanted you out of town.
That's all. He didn't say how, just out of town.
Your brother was my friend, Jack. I wouldn't hurt him.
Yeah.
Give me a name or this is going to another level.
Cyrus Paice.
[GUN HAMMER CLICKS]
JACK: You want me out?! Huh? You want me out?!
You wanna do this? You wanna do this?
Rabbit's out of the hat. Let's see if it jumps.
What'd you do to Richie? Damn you! I didn't do nothing.
I hate to be the bearer of bad news,
but you're chasing your ass.
You were gone too long, brother. Shit changes.
Maybe not you, but some shit does change.
You brother, your precious brother, Richie,
was no goddamn saint.
Everybody's into something. Plain and simple, all right?
There's no mystery, no intrigue.
He got juiced up one night. He got oiled up
and he wrapped his sorry ass around a tree.
End of story.
Now, if you wanna do this little dance here
for old time's sake, Jack, bring it.
Let me tell you something, you're gonna end up
like a one-legged man in an ass-kicking contest.
I'm tired of your bullshit, Jack. I'm a businessman.
I got ladies waiting for me on the inside.
Grow up, Jack.
[SIREN WAILING IN DISTANCE]
♪ Silent night ♪
♪ Holy night... ♪
DOREEN: Uncle Jack.
I didn't think you were gonna show up.
I was in the neighborhood, you know?
Listen, I'm having one of those year-long nights.
I don't know if I'd be fun to be around.
Maybe we ought to take a rain check on this.
Okay?
Okay. All right.
Bye. I'll give you a call tomorrow.
Doreen.
You hungry?
A little.
You drink coffee? Mm, yeah.
I smoke too.
I don't know if that's worth bragging about, do you?
You smoke.
Well, I did. But I just recently quit.
Oh, yeah? When?
Oh, I'd say about...
now.
So if you don't mind.
Makes you nuts, doesn't it?
It's having an impact, yes.
You are so freaky.
Well, we're all a little freaky, Doreen.
It's those straight ones we gotta worry about.
So, what do you do, like, for work?
What'd your father tell you? He didn't.
That's good.
Mom said you were a gambler.
Isn't that illegal?
[CHUCKLES]
Are you a bookie?
Bookie? No. More like, um...
More like a financial adjuster.
[DOREEN CHUCKLES SOFTLY]
So you ever been to prison?
For how long? How about this weather?
Come on.
What do you say we change the subject?
All right. Fine.
You ever shoot anybody?
[CHUCKLES]
You wanna know what I do for a living?
Simple. People make promises and they break them.
My job is to refresh their memory.
That's about it. No big deal.
What's with the clothes?
What's with the jewelry in your face?
Heh. You don't like it?
It's nice. Heh.
You ever been married?
I don't think so.
So you don't have a family of your own.
What are you?
[CRICKETS CHIRPING]
DOREEN: Why'd you leave?
JACK: Well, Doreen, that's a long, long story.
DOREEN: It's a long, long ride.
[CHUCKLES]
Let's put it this way.
You ever wanna take every mirror in the world and get rid of it
because you didn't like what was coming back at you?
Yeah.
[CHUCKLES SOFTLY]
I wish my dad was here.
Me too.
Do you, um...?
Do you really think somebody killed him?
Yeah, I think so, but...
Me too.
So do you have a license yet? Yep.
What, did you, like, learn that in school?
Dad taught me. Oh, yeah?
[DOG BARKING IN DISTANCE]
Doreen, would you wait in the car?
Why? Why? It's all right.
Wait in the car. I'll be right back.
It's okay. It's okay.
RECORDED VOICE [OVER PHONE]: If you'd like to make a call,
please hang up and try again.
If you need help, hang up and then dial the operator.
[LINE BEEPING]
[GUNSHOTS]
GLORIA: Jack.
You all right? Have you seen Doreen?
What happened? Who did it? I have no idea where she is.
He came-- I don't know. He came in. I...
Are you okay? You all right? It's gonna be all right.
Really.
Why'd they do this? I don't know.
But I'm gonna find out, you can believe that.
Come on, let's go get your mom. Where are we going?
I want you guys to stay with me tonight, okay?
Gloria, why don't we get out of here?
Yeah. I'm fine. I'm okay.
I need to talk to your Uncle Jack alone.
Come on.
[POLICE OFFICERS CHATTERING]
JACK: What's wrong?
GLORIA: I need you to leave. JACK: What?
My mom's coming over. We're gonna go to her place tonight.
We're gonna stay there. Listen, I know that you wanna help.
But just look around you.
Look what you brought into my house. Look at my face.
Look at my family. You're not helping, Jack.
So please go.
Wait. What are you say--? I brought in--?
I didn't bring anything into this--
Gloria. Look, I just wanna know the truth.
What the hell was Richie into?
Oh, God.
Okay.
Oh, my head hurts. That's all right.
Whatever this costs, I'll just take care of it, all right?
I think maybe you and Doreen wanna get out of town.
Take a vacation. I'll take care of that too.
You shouldn't be here. Just-- We're fine. We're fine.
Just go.
[GROANS SOFTLY]
I'm sorry, Gloria.
